Your gifts bear out a distinction of which both Baltimore and the University are
proud, namely,,the linking of
commerce with learning. The
city, having earned •a name

the world, has brought not a
little of its wealth to be deposited to the service of its.
body of scholars ; similarly,
the University has been proud
of its situation in a 'great
business community, and has
sought to use Baltimore as a
laboratory of observation.
Political Economy in a sense
had its birth iii. such a partnership, for a century and a
half ago Adam Smith drew
verification from the merchants of Clyde, and was in
turn honored by them.
Eminent men of affairs have
traditionally regarded the
philosophy of trade as of
fundamental interest, and
front them have flowed litany
contributions to economic
science. David Ricardo moved

regeneration of his own manufacturing village, entered into a wider apostleship; Walter Bagehot, acquainted with
the realities of Lombard
Street, dispelled its mysteries
for any who would read.

amount. You have been anxious to see your means'devoted

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 19, 1926.

AVOIDABLE UNPLEASANTNESS
The Saturday night dances at Hopkins have always been a
great institution. Here, at least in theory, the hard-working
undergraduate, after a week presumably filled with study, may
relax and enjoy himself without sacrificing the college atmosphere. The crowd, composed of his associates on the campus,
is congenial, the music good, the price low, in fact, conditions
seem to be ideal. .
But, as we have long since discovered, ideal conditions rarely
correspond with facts. For several weeks, one of the unpleasant features of the Saturday night has been the indescriminate
parking of cars around the Civil Engineering Building. In
spite of the fact that there is ample parking space at .the end
of the drive, a few yards farther on, machines have been driven'
over the grass with no regard for the subsequent appearance of
the campus.
More unpleasant accounts, however, have reached us since the
dance last Saturday night. It seems that guests wandered
about the dance floor With their hats on, unmindful of suggestions that it might be better to remove ;them. Throwing blackboard erasers provided amusement for Others and hat crushing in the men's cloak room proved popular. To cap the climax, someone appropriated a senior's car which was standing
directly in front of the building.
We do not wish to apply a coat of whitewash to every'Hopkin's man, but it is certain that outsiders, who have,been attending the dances-in increasing numbers, were responsible for most
of the misconduct.
The Gptillion Board should revert to its original policy of
restricting attendance to Hopkins graduates and undergraduates, and to any friends who may accompany them.

IT'S WORTH IT!
- --Half-the time allotted-to the Spring Season Ticket campaign
has passed, and not enough tickets have been sold to pay for
the expenses of the drive.
Most of the selling teams have fallen down on the job; and
a general apathy prevails on the campus; the prospect of a dismal failure does not seem to have changed the attitude of "let
the others do it." No worse spirit could develop among the.
student body, and it cOuld come at no worse time. We are not
exaggerating when we make the statement that the outcome of
the present ticket drive will profoundly affect all future athletics at Hopkins.
Dr.. Goodnow has announced that we will have athletics as
long as they are self-supporting, and as long as the students
show that they want athletics. Our athletics are neither overorganized nor over emphasized, but they cannot be run on nothing—and the money must come either from gate receipts or
season ticket sales.
Already, baseball has been dropped on account of its expense.
The fate of the two remaining spring sports rests with you—or
rather us, for the NEWS-LETTER does not wish to dodge the responsibility. Indifference toward the campaign will cripple
athletics, and will go far toward convincing the Board of Trustees that the students no longer want athletics. Loyal support
of the drive will put lacrosse and track on their feet, and will
prove that we still want sports.
• There is no middle course. 'Get out and sell tickets—it's
worth it.

Colt and Cleveland stationed
themselves before the doors of the
Dining Hall one evening and made
a large haul for June Week. It
was amusing to note that the
crowd, which usually gathers in
the Main Hall, had that evening
retreated to the Commons Room,
and for once seemed to find great
pleasure in the usually very dry
magazines.
These two men put up a valiant
defense but they were overwhelmed
when the doors were opened, and
many residents, whose lapels did
not wear a June Week button,
managed to eat dinner in spite of
their hard hearts.
* *
Shevshefsky, a graduate student
in chemistry, talked at a dormitory discussion group on the conditions in Russia. He gave interesting information concerning the
governmental, educational, and religious
of that country.
He also spoke briefly of the events
relating to the revolution and the
effect of the revolution on Russian
life.

New opponents on next fall's

Pennsylvania, which has never before played Hopkins; Loyola College, which shows promise of being

who defeated Hopkins last year;
the University of Richmond and

lost to Hopkins by narrow margins last fall;St. Johns, which held
Hopkins to a 7-7 tie; and the University of Maryland, which has

seasons.
An organization meeting of candidates for the spring season
squad and for assistant managers
will shortly be announced.

Political Economy in a sense
had its birth iii. such a partnership, for a century and a
half ago Adam Smith drew
verification from the merchants of Clyde, and was in
turn honored by them.

traditionally regarded the

fundamental interest, and
front them have flowed litany

Street, dispelled its mysteries
for any who would read.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 19, 1926.

AVOIDABLE UNPLEASANTNESS
The Saturday night dances at Hopkins have always been a
great institution. Here, at least in theory, the hard-working
undergraduate, after a week presumably filled with study, may
relax and enjoy himself without sacrificing the college atmosphere. The crowd, composed of his associates on the campus,
is congenial, the music good, the price low, in fact, conditions
seem to be ideal. .
But, as we have long since discovered, ideal conditions rarely
correspond with facts. For several weeks, one of the unpleasant features of the Saturday night has been the indescriminate
parking of cars around the Civil Engineering Building. In
spite of the fact that there is ample parking space at .the end
of the drive, a few yards farther on, machines have been driven'
over the grass with no regard for the subsequent appearance of
the campus.
More unpleasant accounts, however, have reached us since the
dance last Saturday night. It seems that guests wandered
about the dance floor With their hats on, unmindful of suggestions that it might be better to remove ;them. Throwing blackboard erasers provided amusement for Others and hat crushing in the men's cloak room proved popular. To cap the climax, someone appropriated a senior's car which was standing
directly in front of the building.
We do not wish to apply a coat of whitewash to every'Hopkin's man, but it is certain that outsiders, who have,been attending the dances-in increasing numbers, were responsible for most
of the misconduct.
The Gptillion Board should revert to its original policy of
restricting attendance to Hopkins graduates and undergraduates, and to any friends who may accompany them.

IT'S WORTH IT!
- --Half-the time allotted-to the Spring Season Ticket campaign
has passed, and not enough tickets have been sold to pay for
the expenses of the drive.
Most of the selling teams have fallen down on the job; and
a general apathy prevails on the campus; the prospect of a dismal failure does not seem to have changed the attitude of "let
the others do it." No worse spirit could develop among the.
student body, and it cOuld come at no worse time. We are not
exaggerating when we make the statement that the outcome of
the present ticket drive will profoundly affect all future athletics at Hopkins.
Dr.. Goodnow has announced that we will have athletics as
long as they are self-supporting, and as long as the students
show that they want athletics. Our athletics are neither overorganized nor over emphasized, but they cannot be run on nothing—and the money must come either from gate receipts or
season ticket sales.
Already, baseball has been dropped on account of its expense.
The fate of the two remaining spring sports rests with you—or
rather us, for the NEWS-LETTER does not wish to dodge the responsibility. Indifference toward the campaign will cripple
athletics, and will go far toward convincing the Board of Trustees that the students no longer want athletics. Loyal support
of the drive will put lacrosse and track on their feet, and will
prove that we still want sports.
• There is no middle course. 'Get out and sell tickets—it's
worth it.

Colt and Cleveland stationed
themselves before the doors of the
Dining Hall one evening and made
a large haul for June Week. It
was amusing to note that the
crowd, which usually gathers in
the Main Hall, had that evening
retreated to the Commons Room,
and for once seemed to find great
pleasure in the usually very dry
magazines.
These two men put up a valiant
defense but they were overwhelmed
when the doors were opened, and
many residents, whose lapels did
not wear a June Week button,
managed to eat dinner in spite of
their hard hearts.
* *
Shevshefsky, a graduate student
in chemistry, talked at a dormitory discussion group on the conditions in Russia. He gave interesting information concerning the
governmental, educational, and religious
of that country.
He also spoke briefly of the events
relating to the revolution and the
effect of the revolution on Russian
life.
